# Repository Guidelines

This workspace is a collection of related KnearMe apps and experiments. Each top‑level folder is a self‑contained project with its own `package.json`, tooling, and (in some cases) its own git history. Always `cd` into the project you’re changing and follow any nested `AGENTS.md` there.

## ExecPlans
When writing complex features or significant refactors, use an ExecPlan (as described in `PLANS.md` at the repository root) from design to implementation. Start from `EXECPLAN_TEMPLATE.md` and keep the plan updated as a living document.

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `knearme-portfolio/` – Next.js 16 + React 19 portfolio/app. Source in `src/`, routes in `src/app/`, public assets in `public/`.
- `directory-platforms/` – directory platform variants:
  - `astro-main/` (Astro + Cloudflare Pages), `v4/` (Vite + Express + Drizzle), `supabase/` (React/Vite client + Express server).
- `rank-tracking/` – pnpm/Turborepo monorepo for rank‑tracking tools (`local-beacon/`, `next-tracker/`).
- `docs/` – product and business documentation; treat as source‑of‑truth for decisions.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
Run from the relevant subproject:
- `npm install` or `pnpm install` – install dependencies.
- `npm run dev` / `pnpm dev` – start local dev server (Next.js, Astro, or Turbo apps).
- `npm run build` / `pnpm build` – production build.
- `npm run lint` / `pnpm lint` – ESLint/Turbo linting.
- Where configured: `npm test`, `npm run test:coverage`, `npm run test:e2e` (Jest/Playwright).

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- TypeScript-first; React components in `PascalCase`, utilities in `camelCase`.
- Respect framework conventions (Next.js App Router, Astro pages, Express routes).
- Formatting/linting is enforced via ESLint and (in some packages) Prettier/Turbo; run lint before pushing.

## Testing Guidelines
- Tests are per-package: Jest or Vitest for unit tests; Playwright for e2e in `astro-main/` and `rank-tracking/`.
- Name tests `*.test.ts` / `*.test.tsx` and colocate under `__tests__/` or the package’s test folder.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Most packages use short, imperative commits; some follow Conventional Commits (`feat:`, `fix:`). Prefer Conventional Commits when unsure.
- PRs should include a clear summary, linked issues, screenshots/GIFs for UI changes, and notes on how you tested. Update `docs/` and `.env.example` when behavior or config changes.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- dev-browser: Browser automation with persistent page state. Use when users ask to navigate websites, fill forms, take screenshots, extract web data, test web apps, or automate browser workflows. Trigger phrases include "go to [url]", "click on", "fill out the form", "take a screenshot", "scrape", "automate", "test the website", "log into", or any browser interaction request. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/dev-browser/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.message:
Here’s what I see in `knearme-portfolio`:

- You’re on a local branch `feature/agent-observability` with **no upstream** set.
- GitHub only has `main` and `feature/typeform-onboarding` right now.
- You also have local changes + an untracked file, so even if you pushed earlier, your working tree isn’t clean.

That’s why it looks “not synced” — the branch you’re on doesn’t exist on GitHub yet, and you have local edits.

If you want it synced, you have two options:
1) Push the current branch: `git push -u origin feature/agent-observability`
2) If you meant to be on `main`, switch and pull: `git switch main` then `git pull`

On the monorepo question:
- I wouldn’t switch unless you’re **frequently making cross‑project changes** or want **shared dependencies/tooling/CI** across all apps.
- Your workspace is already structured as separate projects with their own tooling and (some) histories — that’s a good fit for a multi‑repo setup.
- A monorepo makes sense if you want atomic changes across apps, a shared UI/package library, or one CI pipeline; otherwise it adds friction.

If you want, tell me what “not synced” means in your case (missing commits? GitHub UI? deployment mismatch?) and I’ll pinpoint the exact fix.

review this pov Let me break down the tradeoffs for your specific situation.                        
                                                                                                     
  Monorepo vs Multi-Repo: Your Context                                                               
                                                                                                     
  Current state:                                                                                     
  - 5 related projects (knearme-portfolio, review-agent-dashboard, contractor-review-agent,          
  business-agent, business-agent-codex)                                                              
  - Shared Supabase backend                                                                          
  - Similar tech stack (TypeScript, Next.js)                                                         
                                                                                                     
  ---                                                                                                
  Option 1: Keep Multi-Repo (Current)                                                                
  ┌──────────────────────────────────┬─────────────────────────────────────────┐                     
  │               Pros               │                  Cons                   │                     
  ├──────────────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────────────────────┤                     
  │ Independent versioning/releases  │ Harder to share code between projects   │                     
  ├───────────────────────────────�──────────────────────┼─────────────────────────────────────────┤                     
  │ Each project has clear ownership │ No unified view of changes              │                     
  └──────────────────────────────────┴─────────────────────────────────────────┘                     
  Best when: Projects are truly independent, different teams, different release cycles.              
                                                                                                     
  ---                                                                                                
  Option 2: True Monorepo                                                                            
  ┌────────�s across projects      │ Larger git history to clone             │                  
  ├─────────────────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────────────────────┤                  
  │ Shared code/types/utils easily      │ CI needs to be smarter (affected paths) │                  
  ├─────────────────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────────────────────┤                  
  │ Single PR for cross-cutting changes │ All projects in one place = busier repo │                  
  ├─────────────────────────────────────┼───────────────────────� dependencies, frequent cross-project changes, small team.                        
                                                                                                     
  ---                                                                                                
  My Assessment for Your Setup                                                                       
                                                                                                     
  Given your situation:                                                                              
  - ✅ Shared Supabase → monorepo helps keep types/schemas in sync                                   
  - ✅ Solo/small team → simpler to manage one repo                                                  
  - ✅ Related projects → the dashboard, agent, and portfolio interact                               
  - ⚠️ But → you'd need Turborepo or similar for efficient builds                                    
                                                                                   
  ★ Insight ─────────────────────────────────────                                                    
  Recommendation: A monorepo with Turborepo would fit well here. You already have the workspace      
  structure - you'd just need to:                                                                    
  1. Create one GitHub repo for knearme-workspace                                                    
  2. Add turbo.json for coordinated builds                                                           
  3. Keep each project as a workspace package

# Repository Guidelines

This workspace is a collection of related KnearMe apps and experiments. Each top‑level folder is a self‑contained project with its own `package.json`, tooling, and (in some cases) its own git history. Always `cd` into the project you’re changing and follow any nested `AGENTS.md` there.

## ExecPlans
When writing complex features or significant refactors, use an ExecPlan (as described in `PLANS.md` at the repository root) from design to implementation. Start from `EXECPLAN_TEMPLATE.md` and keep the plan updated as a living document.

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `knearme-portfolio/` – Next.js 16 + React 19 portfolio/app. Source in `src/`, routes in `src/app/`, public assets in `public/`.
- `directory-platforms/` – directory platform variants:
  - `astro-main/` (Astro + Cloudflare Pages), `v4/` (Vite + Express + Drizzle), `supabase/` (React/Vite client + Express server).
- `rank-tracking/` – pnpm/Turborepo monorepo for rank‑tracking tools (`local-beacon/`, `next-tracker/`).
- `docs/` – product and business documentation; treat as source‑of‑truth for decisions.

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
Run from the relevant subproject:
- `npm install` or `pnpm install` – install dependencies.
- `npm run dev` / `pnpm dev` – start local dev server (Next.js, Astro, or Turbo apps).
- `npm run build` / `pnpm build` – production build.
- `npm run lint` / `pnpm lint` – ESLint/Turbo linting.
- Where configured: `npm test`, `npm run test:coverage`, `npm run test:e2e` (Jest/Playwright).

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- TypeScript-first; React components in `PascalCase`, utilities in `camelCase`.
- Respect framework conventions (Next.js App Router, Astro pages, Express routes).
- Formatting/linting is enforced via ESLint and (in some packages) Prettier/Turbo; run lint before pushing.

## Testing Guidelines
- Tests are per-package: Jest or Vitest for unit tests; Playwright for e2e in `astro-main/` and `rank-tracking/`.
- Name tests `*.test.ts` / `*.test.tsx` and colocate under `__tests__/` or the package’s test folder.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Most packages use short, imperative commits; some follow Conventional Commits (`feat:`, `fix:`). Prefer Conventional Commits when unsure.
- PRs should include a clear summary, linked issues, screenshots/GIFs for UI changes, and notes on how you tested. Update `docs/` and `.env.example` when behavior or config changes.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- dev-browser: Browser automation with persistent page state. Use when users ask to navigate websites, fill forms, take screenshots, extract web data, test web apps, or automate browser workflows. Trigger phrases include "go to [url]", "click on", "fill out the form", "take a screenshot", "scrape", "automate", "test the website", "log into", or any browser interaction request. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/dev-browser/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/aaronbaker/knearme-workspace/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.message:
**Findings**
- The current-state facts look incomplete/possibly inaccurate. This workspace has more than 5 top‑level projects (e.g., `rank-tracking/`, `directory-platforms/`, `docs/`), so the scope statement is misleading and will bias the recommendation.
- “Shared Supabase backend” is asserted as fact without evidence. If any apps are decoupled or use different backends, the monorepo “sync types/schemas” benefit weakens.
- The recommendation jumps to “monorepo with Turborepo” without weighing migration costs: repo history rewriting, CI/CD changes, deploy pipelines, access control, and third‑party integrations (Vercel/Cloudflare) are non‑trivial.
- The tradeoff tables are malformed (broken box lines / garbled characters), which makes the message hard to read and undermines clarity.
- “Solo/small team → simpler to manage one repo” isn’t always true: one repo can be simpler operationally, but can also increase cognitive load and CI noise without strong tooling.
- The decision criteria omit key factors: deployment independence, permission boundaries, and whether shared code truly exists (or is just “similar stack”).

**Open questions / assumptions**
- Are there shared packages or a real need to share code/types across apps today?
- Are release cadences aligned, or do you need independent deploys?
- Are you using separate CI/CD pipelines per app (e.g., Vercel, Cloudflare) that would become more complex in a monorepo?

If you want, I can rewrite this POV into a cleaner, decision‑ready version once you confirm: actual projects in scope, whether Supabase is truly shared across all of them, and how you deploy each app today.

payload.message:
Got it — shared backend confirmed. That strengthens the monorepo case, but I’d still make the recommendation conditional on deployment independence and shared-code needs.

Here’s a tighter, corrected POV with that assumption baked in:

Monorepo vs Multi‑Repo (Your Context)
Current state:
- Multiple related apps in one workspace
- Shared Supabase backend
- Similar TS/Next.js stack

Option 1: Keep Multi‑Repo
Pros
- Independent deploys and release cadence
- Smaller repos, simpler CI per app
- Clear boundaries if you split ownership later
Cons
- Harder to share types/schemas/utilities across apps
- More drift risk (backend changes ripple)
- More duplicated config/infra work

Best when: apps ship independently, limited shared code, or distinct hosting/permissions.

Option 2: Monorepo (Turborepo or similar)
Pros
- Shared backend → easier to keep types/schemas in sync
- One PR for cross‑app changes
- Shared tooling/config reduces duplication
Cons
- CI and deploys need “affected‑only” logic
- Larger repo and more background noise
- Migration cost for history/CI/hosting

Best when: frequent cross‑app changes, shared backend types, small team.

Recommendation (given shared backend)
Lean toward monorepo if:
- You often change backend types and update multiple apps
- You want shared packages (types/utils/ui)
- You’re OK investing in Turbo + CI config

If not, stay multi‑repo and add:
- A shared types package published or as a git submodule
- Automated schema/type generation to reduce drift

If you want, tell me how you deploy each app today (Vercel, Cloudflare, etc.) and I’ll give you a concrete migration plan or a “stay multi‑repo but fix drift” plan.
